TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
 ERCP - At [**2169-9-23**] 07:05 PM
   proceedure finished at [**2084**]
   - gen [**Doctor First Name 91**] following w patient; pt under gen [**Doctor First Name 91**] attending
   - ERCP done overnight and stent placed in common bile duct
   - Renal consult called, will see pt [**9-24**] AM
   - cannot get pt to oxygenate well (pre- and post-ERCP), 86% O2sat even
   on Fi02 100%, PEEP increased to 20 and tried decreased to 12; pt in
   reverse trendelenberg, attempted alveolar recruitment maneuver,
   paralyzed pt w cyscuronium
   - esophageal balloon placed
   - afib w RVR w rate 120s with bursts into 150s-190s
   - LR boluses, vasopressin and levophed
   - repleted lots of Ca w calcium gluconate --> due to saponification, Ca
   keeps going down, so keep repleting (so that pressors can still work,
   etc)
   - albumin 5% given w LR over 2hrs
   - 2:30am: ventricular rates more frequently in 170s-190s, hitting 200s
   occasionally but occasionally comes back down to 110s on its own; gave
   IV lopressor 5mg push, pressures dropped to 70s systolic
   - levophed maxed, vasopressin continued, added phenylephrine
   - started amiodarone bolus + drip (hung at 0330)
   - started dilt drip b/c responded well to 5mg IV dilt-->  HR in 90s
   this AM
   Allergies:
   Indomethacin
   Unknown;
   Last dose of Antibiotics:

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:15.3/32.1/1.3, ALT / AST:62/78, Alk Phos / T
   Bili:43/6.9, Amylase / Lipase:1381/576, Differential-Neuts:74.5 %,
   Lymph:19.7 %, Mono:4.8 %, Eos:0.5 %, Fibrinogen:615 mg/dL, Lactic
   Acid:2.9 mmol/L, Albumin:2.6 g/dL, LDH:989 IU/L, Ca++:7.2 mg/dL,
   Mg++:2.2 mg/dL, PO4:6.3 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   55 yo male with pmh of htn and asthma trasnferred from an OSH for
   worsening gallstone pancreatitis complicated by hypoxia, hypotension,
   and acute renal failure.
   .
   # Hypercapneic and Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  Likely ARDS. The
   patient was intubated yesterday morning due to tachypnea and hypoxia in
   the setting of receiving many liters of IVF while oliguric.  Since
   transfer to [**Hospital1 5**] ICU, has had difficulty maintaining oxygenation,
   despite alveolar recruitment maneuvers, positioning of bed, very
   elevated PEEP, esophageal balloon pressures.  Slowly desaturating
   further into 80s%.  Lung compliance low, and peak pressures 35-40,
   which suggest stiff lungs. Has an associated respiratory acidosis.
   - push ETT in 2cm further
   - increase tidal volumes and increase peak pressures; goal to increase
   pH to 7.3 and stabilize
   - increase PEEP further
   - Check serial ABGs to assess ventilation.
   - Propofol and fentanyl prn for sedation.
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  Not responsive to fluids.  Was on three
   pressors last night briefly but weaned off phenylephrine
was just
   needed in the setting of BP drop after IV metoprolol bolused.  CVP
   estimated to be about 5.
   - Levophed prn + vasopressin to maintain MAPs>65.
   - Will follow CVP and continue with aggressive IVF (LR) fluid repletion
   given 3rd spacing physiology with pancreatitis.
   - f/u  blood cultures, UA, and UCx
   - Zosyn, renally dosed due to concern for possible cholangitis +
   Vancomycin
   .
   # Acute renal failure:
   Cr  increased further from 4.2 to 5.2 and oliguric.  Likely  ATN but
   possibly has postrenal obstruction or other intrarenal causes such as
   AIN.  Renal consult this AM called.
   - f/u renal recs  b/c may need CVVH in the near future if he remains
   oliguric and his K continues to rise.
   - f/u urine lytes.
   - Trend Cr.
   - Renal US to rule out postrenal cause.
   - Renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stone still in place.  CBD stent placed
   by ERCP fellow.  Likely will worsen 24hrs post procedure before he can
   get better b/c of transient bacteremia caused by procedure.  Have
   repleted calcium significantly overnight
   - replete calcium as necessary for continued drop due to
   saponification. Improving lipase and amylase.
   - f/u ERCP/GI recs
   - Will f/u surgery recs.
   - NPO with IVF
bolus as needed for pressures
   - Trend his LFTs and pancreatic enzymes
   .
   # Hyperglycemia:  The patient does not have known history of diabetes,
   however was found to have sugars in the 500's at the OSH so he likely
   had underlying type II diabetes.  He was weaned off the insulin gtt
   prior to transfer.  no documentation sent with the amount of insulin he
   received by insulin gtt at outside hospital
   - continue to check q6h fingersticks and cover with SSI.  Will add up
   his 24 hour requirements and start a long-acting [**Doctor Last Name **].
   .
   # Anemia: The patient's Hct stable at 38.  Guaiac + diarrhea.
   - Active type and screen.
   - Continue to trend.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia:  His platelets are 156 which is stable in last
   couple days. (platelets 202 at outside hospital admission)
   - Continue to trend.
   .
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   NPO
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2169-9-23**] 09:11 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2169-9-23**] 09:13 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2169-9-24**] 05:40 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: subq heparin
   Stress ulcer: ppi
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: full
   Disposition:

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma who was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis complicated by hypoxia, hypotension, and acute renal failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and has difficulty maintaining oxygenation despite alveolar recruitment maneuvers, positioning of the bed, and elevated PEEP. The patient has an associated respiratory acidosis, with a pH of 7.24 and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 56.
* Cardiac: The patient is tachycardic with a heart rate of 170 beats per minute and has a normal blood pressure of 112/72 mmHg.
* Renal: The patient has acute renal failure with a creatinine level of 5.2 mg/dL and is oliguric.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has gallstone pancreatitis with a CBD stone still in place and has undergone ERCP with stent placement.
* Hematological: The patient has anemia with a hemoglobin level of 12.9 g/dL and thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 156 K/uL.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and further deterioration may lead to respiratory failure.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension may lead to cardiac arrest.
* Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and oliguria may be indicative of sepsis.
* Acute tubular necrosis: The patient's acute renal failure may be caused by acute tubular necrosis.
* Pancreatitis: The patient's gallstone pancreatitis may worsen and lead to further complications.
* Infection: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia may be indicative of infection.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Respiratory support: The patient will continue to receive mechanical ventilation and alveolar recruitment maneuvers to improve oxygenation.
* Cardiac support: The patient will continue to receive vasopressor support to maintain blood pressure.
* Renal support: The patient will continue to receive fluid repletion and may require continuous renal replacement therapy if oliguria persists.
* Gastrointestinal support: The patient will continue to receive IV fluids and may require surgical intervention if the CBD stone is not removed.
* Hematological support: The patient will continue to receive blood transfusions and may require platelet transfusions if thrombocytopenia persists.

Overall, the patient's condition is unstable, and close monitoring and aggressive management are necessary to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis complicated by hypoxia, hypotension, and acute renal failure. He underwent ERCP and stent placement in the common bile duct, but is still experiencing difficulty maintaining oxygenation and has required multiple pressors to maintain blood pressure.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 38.6°C (101.4°F)
* Heart rate: 170 bpm (with bursts into 150s-190s)
* Blood pressure: 112/72 mmHg (with occasional drops to 70s systolic)
* Respiratory rate: 35 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 83%
* SpO2: 83%

The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, with a FiO2 of 100% and PEEP of 18 cmH2O. He is also receiving vasopressors (levophed and vasopressin) to maintain blood pressure.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 17.1 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 12.9 g/dL
* Platelet count: 156 K/uL
* Creatinine: 5.2 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 243 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: potassium 26 mEq/L, sodium 140 mEq/L, chloride 100 mEq/L
* Glucose: 500 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Sclera icteric and scleral edema
* Small and equal pupils
* Tachycardic and regular heartbeat
* Normal S1 and S2 heart sounds
* No murmurs, rubs, or gallops
* Abdomen distended and tympanic
* Foley catheter present

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's difficulty maintaining oxygenation and requiring multiple pressors to maintain blood pressure increases the risk of respiratory failure.
* Septic shock: The patient's hypotension and oliguria, despite fluid resuscitation, may indicate septic shock.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's increasing creatinine and oliguria may indicate acute kidney injury.
* Hyperglycemia: The patient's glucose level of 500 mg/dL and lack of known diabetes history may indicate hyperglycemia.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count of 156 K/uL may indicate thrombocytopenia.
* Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level of 12.9 g/dL may indicate anemia.
* Cholangitis: The patient's gallstone pancreatitis and CBD stone may increase the risk of cholangitis.
* Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may worsen over the next 24 hours due to transient bacteremia caused by the ERCP procedure.

Based on the patient's condition, the plan includes:

* Continuation of mechanical ventilation and pressor support
* Monitoring of serial ABGs to assess ventilation
* Propofol and fentanyl for sedation as needed
* Repletion of calcium as necessary due to saponification
* Follow-up with ERCP and surgery recommendations
* NPO with IV fluids as needed for pressure support
* Trending of LFTs and pancreatic enzymes
* Levophed and vasopressin to maintain MAPs > 65
* Renal consult to rule out postrenal cause of acute renal failure
* Renal dosing of medications and avoidance of nephrotoxins
* Hyperglycemia management with insulin as needed
* Anemia and thrombocytopenia monitoring
* Cholangitis and pancreatitis management as needed.

   which suggest stiff lungs. Has an associated respiratory acidosis.

was just

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma who was transferred to the ICU from the emergency department with worsening gallstone pancreatitis complicated by hypoxia, hypotension, and acute renal failure. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His respiratory status is critical, with hypercapnic and hypoxic respiratory failure likely due to ARDS. He has been treated with various pressors and has been weaned off phenylephrine. His blood pressure is still unstable, and his CVP is estimated to be around 5.

The patient's renal function is compromised, with a creatinine level of 5.2 mg/dL and oliguria. He has been diagnosed with acute tubular necrosis (ATN), and a renal consult has been called. He has also been diagnosed with cholangitis, and a CBD stent was placed by ERCP.

The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, with hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia. His albumin level is low, and he has been treated with albumin infusions. His platelet count is stable, but his hemoglobin level is low.

The patient's glucose level is elevated, and he has been diagnosed with hyperglycemia. He has been treated with insulin and is receiving a long-acting insulin.

The patient's overall condition is critical, and he requires close monitoring and treatment.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may develop further respiratory failure if his oxygenation and ventilation do not improve.
2. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and he may develop further renal failure if his oliguria persists.
3. Septic shock: The patient's blood pressure is still unstable, and he may develop septic shock if his blood pressure does not improve.
4. Infection: The patient has been diagnosed with cholangitis, and he may develop further infections if his bile duct is not cleared.
5. Pancreatitis: The patient has been diagnosed with pancreatitis, and he may develop further complications if his pancreatitis does not improve.
6. Hypocalcemia: The patient's calcium level is low, and he may develop further complications if his calcium level does not improve.
7. Hypomagnesemia: The patient's magnesium level is low, and he may develop further complications if his magnesium level does not improve.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient's glucose level is elevated, and he may develop further complications if his hyperglycemia does not improve.
9. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, and he may develop further complications if his anemia does not improve.
10. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is stable, but he may develop further complications if his platelet count decreases.

   in the setting of receiving many liters of IVF while oliguric.
   Initially, had difficulty maintaining oxygenation, despite alveolar
   recruitment maneuvers, positioning of bed, very elevated PEEP,
   esophageal balloon pressures.  Change of bed with 35 degree tilting
   appeared to help oxygenation as his vent settings have decreased.
   - Attempt to wean down vent settings as patient can
   - Check serial ABGs to assess ventilation.
   - Propofol and fentanyl prn for sedation.
   - Continue bed positioning
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  Intermittent fluid boluses are not clear
   if helpful as difficult to assess volume status.  Was intially on three
   pressors; weaned off phenylephrine and levophed dose is decreasing as
   well. Also with new fever spike while on broad spectrum antibiotics.
   - Continue to wean levophed + vasopressin to maintain MAPs>65.
   - Will follow change in CVP and attempts to continue with IVF
   resusciation given 3rd spacing physiology with pancreatitis, but to be
   careful with tenous respiratory status
   - f/u  blood cultures, Ucx
s and sputum cultures
   - Zosyn, renally dosed due to concern for possible cholangitis +
   Vancomycin renally dosed
   .
   # Acute renal failure:
   Cr  increased further from 5.9 to 6.9 this AM.  Likely  ATN highest on
   differential at this point.
   - Patient s/p IR HD femoral line placement
   - Contact renal  b/c may likely need CVVH today as patient is getting
   fluids and not urinating
   - f/u urine lytes: Fe Urea: 9.43%; likely pre-renal state
   - Trend Cr.
   - Renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   - Follow bladder pressures and lactate
if continuing to increase
   consider calling surgery for possible decompression of compartment
   syndrome
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient on amio and dilt gtt to control HR.
   Patient with adequately controlled rate on these two medications.
   -  Stop dilt gtt today as patient as heart rate is well controlled
   -  Continue amio gtt
   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stone still in place.  CBD stent placed
   by ERCP fellow.  Likely will worsen 24hrs post procedure before he can
   get better b/c of transient bacteremia caused by procedure.  Have
   repleted calcium significantly overnight
   - replete calcium as necessary for continued drop due to
   saponification. Improving lipase and amylase.
   - f/u ERCP/GI recs
   - Will f/u surgery recs.
   - NPO with IVF
bolus as needed for pressures
   - Trend his LFTs and pancreatic enzymes
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred from an outside hospital (OSH) for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 21 cmH2O and FiO2 of 80%. His oxygen saturation is 92%. He has a slight wheeze in his lungs.
* Cardiovascular: The patient is tachycardic with a heart rate of 86 bpm and is on multiple pressors, including vasopressin, norepinephrine, and amiodarone, to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) > 65 mmHg.
* Renal: The patient has acute renal failure with a creatinine level of 6.9 mg/dL and is oliguric. He is receiving intermittent fluid boluses and is likely to require continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) or hemodialysis.
* Hepatic: The patient has gallstone pancreatitis and has undergone ERCP with CBD stenting. He has a significant drop in his calcium levels and is at risk for saponification.
* Hematological: The patient has thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 107 K/uL and is at risk for bleeding.
* Endocrine: The patient has hyperglycemia and is receiving insulin therapy.

The patient's potential medical complications are:

* Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient's P/F ratio is 84, indicating a high risk of ARDS. He is at risk for further respiratory deterioration and may require more aggressive ventilatory support.
* Septic shock: The patient's MAP is < 65 mmHg, indicating a high risk of organ dysfunction. He is at risk for further cardiovascular instability and may require more aggressive pressor therapy.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is increasing, indicating a high risk of further renal dysfunction. He is at risk for further fluid overload and may require CRRT or hemodialysis.
* Pancreatitis: The patient's gallstone pancreatitis is likely to worsen in the next 24 hours due to transient bacteremia caused by the ERCP procedure. He is at risk for further pancreatic enzyme elevation and may require further medical therapy.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, indicating a high risk of bleeding. He is at risk for further thrombocytopenia and may require platelet transfusions.
* Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood sugar levels are high, indicating a high risk of further hyperglycemia. He is at risk for further end-organ damage and may require more aggressive insulin therapy.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue mechanical ventilation with PEEP of 21 cmH2O and FiO2 of 80%.
* Wean pressors as tolerated to maintain MAP > 65 mmHg.
* Continue insulin therapy to control hyperglycemia.
* Monitor for signs of further respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal deterioration.
* Consider CRRT or hemodialysis for acute renal failure.
* Monitor for signs of further pancreatitis and adjust medical therapy as necessary.
* Monitor for signs of bleeding and consider platelet transfusions as necessary.
* Continue to trend the patient's laboratory values and adjust therapy as necessary.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has hypoxic respiratory failure, and there is a risk of further deterioration. The patient's oxygen saturation is still in the mid-80s, and the partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) is 84, indicating that the patient is still not fully oxygenated.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level has increased from 5.9 to 6.9 mg/dL, indicating worsening renal function. The patient is at risk of developing AKI, which can lead to further complications such as electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
3. Septic shock: The patient is still on vasopressors and has a high central venous pressure (CVP), indicating ongoing septic shock. The patient's blood pressure is still labile, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient is on amiodarone and diltiazem to control their heart rate, but there is a risk of further arrhythmias or cardiac complications.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient has a history of hyperglycemia, and there is a risk of further hyperglycemic episodes, especially with the patient's ongoing stress and sepsis.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is still low, and there is a risk of further bleeding complications.
7. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is stable, but there is a risk of further anemia due to ongoing bleeding or hemolysis.
8. Pancreatitis: The patient has ongoing pancreatitis, and there is a risk of further complications such as pancreatic abscesses or fistulas.
9. Bacteremia: The patient has a history of bacteremia, and there is a risk of further bacteremia or sepsis.
10. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has a history of hypertension and asthma, and there is a risk of further cardiovascular complications such as myocardial infarction or cardiac failure.

The patient's ongoing medical issues and potential complications require close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration and improve their overall outcome.

   On this day I examined the patient and reviewed his hospital course to
   date. I have also gone over his labs, hemodynamics, imaging, and vent
   settings and status, and have spent considerable time at the bedside
   with RRT
s on the patient
s vent settings.  I have also reviewed Dr
   [**Last Name (STitle) 9271**]
s note above. I agree with her findings and plan of care.  Mr
   [**Known lastname 9314**] remains very critically ill with sepsis from cholangitis,
   pancreatitis, ARDS, hypotension, renal failure, and intrabdominal
   hypertension.
   Regarding his ARDS, he
s some better with rotating bed which seems to
   help decrease the effect of his tense abdomen on his vent status.  None
   the less he
s tenous, on PEEP of 20 or more, 100% Fi02, and barely
   adequate sats and P02.  His lungs are stiff, and opacified.  Esophageal
   balloon pressured are not exactly making sense as they calculate to a
   TPP at inspiration that
s very small or negative.  TPP at end
   exhalation also neg. For now we
ll keep PEEP at 20 and be sure he
   tanked up.  Unfortunately if we use esoph press as indicator of Ppl
   then his corrected CVP is neg!  Hence for now we
ll correct CVP for
   PEEP (assume 25% of PEEP transmitted to pleural space pressure).  Thus
   his corrected CVP is 23-5 = 18 which is about where we
d want him.
   Unfortunately he
s still needing pressors though for now he
s not
   acidotic and lactate is surprisingly normal, suggesting his abdominal
   pressures are not causing gut ischemia.  Yet his abdomen is very large
   and tense with bladder pressures of 18-20.  I would appreciate surgery
   coming by and commenting on what criteria they
d use for surgical
   decompression. I would also seek their advice on how to decompress pt
   abdomen non surgically  (another trial of colonic airl decompression
   via catheter or c
scope?)
   Femoral HD line is in place though for now I think we have to be
   careful about removing any fluid via CVVH and he doesn
t need HD for
   electrolyte imbalance.
   His pancreatitis by amylase/lipase is subsiding, though he
s needed
   lots of calcium.  His WBC suggests his cholangitis is resolving as
   well.  He has a central line placed in OSH but right now it
s too risky
   to replace this line.
   His sister has been visiting and his attorney/proxy has made the
   patient DNR, not unreasonable given the current acuity and multiplicity
   of his problems.

   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  ARDS likely as p/f ratio is 84 this AM.
   The patient was intubated Saturday morning due to tachypnea and hypoxia
   in the setting of receiving many liters of IVF while oliguric.
   Initially, had difficulty maintaining oxygenation, despite alveolar
   recruitment maneuvers, positioning of bed, very elevated PEEP,
   esophageal balloon pressures.  Change of bed with 35 degree tilting
   appeared to help oxygenation as his vent settings have decreased.
   - Attempt to wean down vent settings as patient can
   - Check serial ABGs to assess ventilation.
   - Propofol and fentanyl prn for sedation.
   - Continue bed positioning
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  Intermittent fluid boluses are not clear
   if helpful as difficult to assess volume status.  Was intially on three
   pressors; weaned off phenylephrine and levophed dose is decreasing as
   well. Also with new fever spike while on broad spectrum antibiotics.
   - Continue to wean levophed + vasopressin to maintain MAPs>65.
   - Will follow change in CVP and attempts to continue with IVF
   resusciation given 3rd spacing physiology with pancreatitis, but to be
   careful with tenous respiratory status
   - f/u  blood cultures, Ucx
s and sputum cultures
   - Zosyn, renally dosed due to concern for possible cholangitis +
   Vancomycin renally dosed
   .
   # Acute renal failure:
   Cr  increased further from 5.9 to 6.9 this AM.  Likely  ATN highest on
   differential at this point.
   - Patient s/p IR HD femoral line placement
   - Contact renal  b/c may likely need CVVH today as patient is getting
   fluids and not urinating
   - f/u urine lytes: Fe Urea: 9.43%; likely pre-renal state
   - Trend Cr.
   - Renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   - Follow bladder pressures and lactate
if continuing to increase
   consider calling surgery for possible decompression of compartment
   syndrome
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient on amio and dilt gtt to control HR.
   Patient with adequately controlled rate on these two medications.
   -  Stop dilt gtt today as patient as heart rate is well controlled
   -  Continue amio gtt
   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stone still in place.  CBD stent placed
   by ERCP fellow.  Likely will worsen 24hrs post procedure before he can
   get better b/c of transient bacteremia caused by procedure.  Have

bolus as needed for pressures

   On this day I examined the patient and reviewed his hospital course to

s on the patient
s vent settings.  I have also reviewed Dr
   [**Last Name (STitle) 9271**]
s note above. I agree with her findings and plan of care.  Mr
   [**Known lastname 9314**] remains very critically ill with sepsis from cholangitis,
   pancreatitis, ARDS, hypotension, renal failure, and intrabdominal
   hypertension.
   Regarding his ARDS, he
s some better with rotating bed which seems to
   help decrease the effect of his tense abdomen on his vent status.  None
   the less he
s tenous, on PEEP of 20 or more, 100% Fi02, and barely
   adequate sats and P02.  His lungs are stiff, and opacified.  Esophageal
   balloon pressured are not exactly making sense as they calculate to a
   TPP at inspiration that
s very small or negative.  TPP at end
   exhalation also neg. For now we
ll keep PEEP at 20 and be sure he
   tanked up.  Unfortunately if we use esoph press as indicator of Ppl
   then his corrected CVP is neg!  Hence for now we
ll correct CVP for
   PEEP (assume 25% of PEEP transmitted to pleural space pressure).  Thus
   his corrected CVP is 23-5 = 18 which is about where we
d want him.
   Unfortunately he
s still needing pressors though for now he
s not
   acidotic and lactate is surprisingly normal, suggesting his abdominal
   pressures are not causing gut ischemia.  Yet his abdomen is very large
   and tense with bladder pressures of 18-20.  I would appreciate surgery
   coming by and commenting on what criteria they
d use for surgical
   decompression. I would also seek their advice on how to decompress pt
   abdomen non surgically  (another trial of colonic airl decompression
   via catheter or c
scope?)
   Femoral HD line is in place though for now I think we have to be
   careful about removing any fluid via CVVH and he doesn
t need HD for
   electrolyte imbalance.
   His pancreatitis by amylase/lipase is subsiding, though he
s needed
   lots of calcium.  His WBC suggests his cholangitis is resolving as
   well.  He has a central line placed in OSH but right now it
s too risky
   to replace this line.
   His sister has been visiting and his attorney/proxy has made the
   patient DNR, not unreasonable given the current acuity and multiplicity
   of his problems.

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. His respiratory status has improved slightly with changes to his bed position and ventilator settings. However, he remains critically ill with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome.

Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's oxygenation remains challenging, and he requires high levels of oxygen and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) to maintain adequate oxygen saturation.
2. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis from cholangitis and pancreatitis, which is complicated by hypotension and oliguric acute renal failure.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine has increased to 6.9 mg/dL, and he is at risk for acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's heart rate is controlled with amiodarone and diltiazem.
5. Gallstone Pancreatitis: The patient has a CBD stone that has not been removed, and he is at risk for further complications.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels are elevated, and he is receiving insulin therapy.
7. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level has decreased to 31.4 g/dL, and he is at risk for further bleeding.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count has decreased to 107, and he is at risk for bleeding.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is precarious, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and hypotension increase his risk for cardiac complications.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic kidney disease or require dialysis.
4. Infections: The patient's sepsis and pancreatitis increase his risk for further infections.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's gallstone pancreatitis and hyperglycemia increase his risk for gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding, perforation, or abscess formation.
6. Hemorrhagic Complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia and anemia increase his risk for bleeding complications.
7. Neurological Complications: The patient's sepsis and hypotension increase his risk for neurological complications such as stroke, seizures, or encephalopathy.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as necessary.
2. Maintain high levels of oxygen and PEEP to ensure adequate oxygenation.
3. Continue antibiotics and antifungal therapy to treat sepsis and pancreatitis.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust therapy as necessary.
5. Consider dialysis or continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) if the patient's creatinine level continues to rise.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust therapy as necessary.
7. Consider surgical decompression of the patient's abdomen if his abdominal pressures continue to increase.
8. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust therapy as necessary.
9. Consider nutritional support with enteral or parenteral nutrition if the patient's oral intake is limited.
10. Monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust therapy as necessary.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Summary:**

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation, acute pancreatitis, acute renal failure, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient has undergone several interventions, including ERCP with CBD stent placement, esophageal balloon placement, and placement of a new HD line for CVVH. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, vasopressin, and amiodarone.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Abdominal Compartment Syndrome:** The patient is at risk for abdominal compartment syndrome due to the presence of an esophageal balloon and the need for continued fluid resuscitation. Monitoring of bladder pressures is essential to prevent this complication.
2. **Fluid Overload:** The patient's fluid balance is positive, which increases the risk of fluid overload and worsening of ARDS. Close monitoring of fluid intake and output is necessary to prevent this complication.
3. **Renal Failure:** The patient's acute renal failure is likely to worsen if not managed properly. Close monitoring of renal function and consideration of further interventions, such as dialysis, may be necessary.
4. **Pneumonia:** The patient is at risk for developing pneumonia due to the presence of an endotracheal tube and the need for mechanical ventilation. Close monitoring of respiratory secretions and consideration of antibiotic therapy may be necessary.
5. **Cardiac Complications:** The patient's atrial fibrillation and need for vasopressin may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest. Close monitoring of cardiac rhythm and function is necessary to prevent these complications.
6. **Pancreatitis:** The patient's acute pancreatitis may worsen if not managed properly. Close monitoring of pancreatic enzymes and consideration of further interventions, such as pancreatic drainage, may be necessary.
7. **Nutritional Complications:** The patient's need for total parenteral nutrition (TPN) may increase the risk of nutritional complications, such as malnutrition or electrolyte imbalances. Close monitoring of nutritional status and electrolyte levels is necessary to prevent these complications.

**Plan:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust mechanical ventilation as necessary to prevent further deterioration.
2. Monitor the patient's fluid balance and adjust fluid intake and output accordingly to prevent fluid overload.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and consider further interventions, such as dialysis, if necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and function and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent cardiac complications.
5. Monitor the patient's pancreatic enzymes and consider further interventions, such as pancreatic drainage, if necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and electrolyte levels and adjust TPN as necessary to prevent nutritional complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   55 yo male with pmh of htn and asthma trasnferred from an OSH for
   worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock complicated by
   hypoxic respiratory failure and oliguric acute renal failure.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  ARDS likely as p/f ratio is 84 this AM.
   The patient was intubated Saturday morning due to tachypnea and hypoxia
   in the setting of receiving many liters of IVF while oliguric.
   Initially, had difficulty maintaining oxygenation, despite alveolar
   recruitment maneuvers, positioning of bed, very elevated PEEP,
   esophageal balloon pressures.  Change of bed with 35 degree tilting
   appeared to help oxygenation as his vent settings have decreased.
   - Attempt to wean down vent settings as patient can
   - Check serial ABGs to assess ventilation.
   - Propofol and fentanyl prn for sedation.
   - Continue bed positioning
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  Intermittent fluid boluses are not clear
   if helpful as difficult to assess volume status.  Was intially on three
   pressors; weaned off phenylephrine and levophed dose is decreasing as
   well. Also with new fever spike while on broad spectrum antibiotics.
   - Continue to wean levophed + vasopressin to maintain MAPs>65.
   - Will follow change in CVP and attempts to continue with IVF
   resusciation given 3rd spacing physiology with pancreatitis, but to be
   careful with tenous respiratory status
   - f/u  blood cultures, Ucx
s and sputum cultures
   - Zosyn, renally dosed due to concern for possible cholangitis +
   Vancomycin renally dosed
   .
   # Acute renal failure:
   Cr  increased further from 6.9 to 7.2 this AM.  Likely  ATN highest on
   differential at this point. Started CVVH yesterday afternoon
   - Continue CVVH to get fluids off
   - f/u urine lytes: Fe Urea: 9.43%; likely pre-renal state
   - Trend Cr.
   - Renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   - Follow bladder pressures and lactate
if continuing to increase
   consider calling surgery for possible decompression of compartment
   syndrome
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient on amio and dilt gtt to control HR.
   Patient with adequately controlled rate on these two medications.
   -  Stop dilt gtt today as patient as heart rate is well controlled
   -  Continue amio gtt
   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stone still in place.  CBD stent placed
   by ERCP fellow.  Likely will worsen 24hrs post procedure before he can
   get better b/c of transient bacteremia caused by procedure.  Have
   repleted calcium significantly overnight
   - replete calcium as necessary for continued drop due to
   saponification. Improving lipase and amylase.
   - f/u ERCP/GI recs
   - Will f/u surgery recs.
   - NPO with IVF
bolus as needed for pressures
   - Trend his LFTs and pancreatic enzymes
   .
   # Hyperglycemia:  The patient does not have known history of diabetes,
   however was found to have sugars in the 500's at the OSH so he likely
   had underlying type II diabetes.  Controlled on an insulin gtt.
   - Continue insulin gtt for now.
   .
   # Anemia: The patient's Hct decreased to 31.4.  Guaiac + diarrhea +
   fluids
   - Active type and screen.
   - Transfuse if Hct < 25
   - Continue to trend.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia:  His platelets are 107 from peak at 157 [**9-24**].
   (platelets 202 at outside hospital admission)
   - Continue to trend.
   - No signs of active bleeding
   - D/C sub q heparin
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. He has undergone ERCP and has a CBD stent in place. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 26 cmH2O and FiO2 of 100%. He is also receiving vasopressin and has been weaned off levophed. His abdominal compartment syndrome is being monitored, and he is at risk for decompression surgery.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure is likely due to ARDS, and he is at risk for further deterioration. Close monitoring of his oxygenation and ventilation is necessary.
2. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's Cr level has increased to 7.2, and he is at risk for further worsening of his renal function. CVVH is being continued to remove fluids and improve oxygenation.
3. Sepsis: The patient has septic shock, and his blood cultures are pending. He is at risk for further organ dysfunction and mortality.
4. Abdominal Compartment Syndrome: The patient's abdominal compartment syndrome is being monitored, and he is at risk for decompression surgery.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is 107, and he is at risk for bleeding.
6. Anemia: The patient's Hct has decreased to 31.3, and he is at risk for further anemia.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood sugar is controlled with an insulin gtt, but he is at risk for further hyperglycemia.
8. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient is being treated with amiodarone and diltiazem to control his heart rate, but he is at risk for further arrhythmias.

Recommendations:

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Continue CVVH to remove fluids and improve oxygenation.
3. Monitor the patient's abdominal compartment syndrome and consider decompression surgery if necessary.
4. Continue to trend the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management accordingly.
5. Monitor the patient's thrombocytopenia and anemia, and consider transfusions if necessary.
6. Continue to control the patient's hyperglycemia with an insulin gtt.
7. Monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma who was transferred from an outside hospital (OSH) for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. He was intubated due to tachypnea and hypoxia and has been receiving mechanical ventilation with high PEEP settings. He has been experiencing difficulty with oxygenation, but repositioning and adjusting PEEP settings have helped improve his oxygenation. He has been receiving vasopressors to maintain his blood pressure and has been weaned off one of the pressors.

The patient has been diagnosed with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), atrial fibrillation, acute renal failure, and hyperglycemia. He has been treated with antibiotics, vasopressors, and insulin, and has undergone ERCP with placement of a CBD stent.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS may worsen, leading to further respiratory failure and the need for more aggressive respiratory support.
2. Septic shock: The patient's septic shock may worsen, leading to further hypotension and the need for more aggressive vasopressor therapy.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further fluid overload and the need for more aggressive dialysis.
4. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may worsen, leading to further complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to further bleeding complications.
6. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's abdominal compartment syndrome may worsen, leading to further respiratory and cardiovascular compromise.
7. Infection: The patient's infection may spread to other parts of his body, leading to further complications such as sepsis.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient will continue to receive mechanical ventilation with high PEEP settings to support his respiratory function. He will also receive vasopressors to maintain his blood pressure and antibiotics to treat his infection. He will undergo further monitoring and testing to assess his respiratory and renal function, and to guide further treatment decisions.

   55 yo male with pmh of htn and asthma trasnferred from an OSH for
   worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock complicated by
   hypoxic respiratory failure and oliguric acute renal failure.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  ARDS likely as p/f ratio is 84 this AM.
   The patient was intubated Saturday morning due to tachypnea and hypoxia
   in the setting of receiving many liters of IVF while oliguric.
   Initially, had difficulty maintaining oxygenation, despite alveolar
   recruitment maneuvers, positioning of bed, very elevated PEEP,
   esophageal balloon pressures.  Change of bed with 35 degree tilting
   appeared to help oxygenation as his vent settings have decreased.
   - Attempt to wean down vent settings as patient can
   - Check serial ABGs to assess ventilation.
   - Propofol and fentanyl prn for sedation.
   - Continue bed positioning
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  Intermittent fluid boluses are not clear
   if helpful as difficult to assess volume status.  Was intially on three
   pressors; weaned off phenylephrine and levophed dose is decreasing as
   well. Also with new fever spike while on broad spectrum antibiotics.
   - Continue to wean levophed + vasopressin to maintain MAPs>65.
   - Will follow change in CVP and attempts to continue with IVF
   resusciation given 3rd spacing physiology with pancreatitis, but to be
   careful with tenous respiratory status
   - f/u  blood cultures, Ucx
s and sputum cultures
   - Zosyn, renally dosed due to concern for possible cholangitis +
   Vancomycin renally dosed
   .
   # Acute renal failure:
   Cr  increased further from 5.9 to 6.9 this AM.  Likely  ATN highest on
   differential at this point.
   - Patient s/p IR HD femoral line placement
   - Contact renal  b/c may likely need CVVH today as patient is getting
   fluids and not urinating
   - f/u urine lytes: Fe Urea: 9.43%; likely pre-renal state
   - Trend Cr.
   - Renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   - Follow bladder pressures and lactate
if continuing to increase
   consider calling surgery for possible decompression of compartment
   syndrome
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient on amio and dilt gtt to control HR.
   Patient with adequately controlled rate on these two medications.
   -  Stop dilt gtt today as patient as heart rate is well controlled
   -  Continue amio gtt
   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stone still in place.  CBD stent placed
   by ERCP fellow.  Likely will worsen 24hrs post procedure before he can
   get better b/c of transient bacteremia caused by procedure.  Have
   repleted calcium significantly overnight
   - replete calcium as necessary for continued drop due to
   saponification. Improving lipase and amylase.
   - f/u ERCP/GI recs
   - Will f/u surgery recs.
   - NPO with IVF
bolus as needed for pressures
   - Trend his LFTs and pancreatic enzymes
   .
   # Hyperglycemia:  The patient does not have known history of diabetes,
   however was found to have sugars in the 500's at the OSH so he likely
   had underlying type II diabetes.  Controlled on an insulin gtt.
   - Continue insulin gtt for now.
   .
   # Anemia: The patient's Hct decreased to 31.4.  Guaiac + diarrhea +
   fluids
   - Active type and screen.
   - Transfuse if Hct < 25
   - Continue to trend.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia:  His platelets are 107 from peak at 157 [**9-24**].
   (platelets 202 at outside hospital admission)
   - Continue to trend.
   - No signs of active bleeding
   - D/C sub q heparin

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. He was intubated due to tachypnea and hypoxia, and has been receiving mechanical ventilation and vasopressors to maintain blood pressure. He has also been treated with antibiotics and has undergone ERCP with CBD stent placement.

Current Status:

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 26 cmH2O and FiO2 of 100%. His oxygenation is improving, but he remains hypoxemic with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 86.
* Cardiovascular: He is receiving vasopressors to maintain a mean arterial pressure of greater than 65 mmHg. His heart rate is regular and normal, but his blood pressure is tachycardic.
* Renal: He is oliguric and has a creatinine level of 6.9 mg/dL. He has been placed on continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) to help remove excess fluids and improve oxygenation.
* Hepatic: His liver function tests are elevated, but his lipase and amylase levels are improving.
* Pancreatic: He has gallstone pancreatitis, and his CBD stone is still in place. He has been treated with ERCP and CBD stent placement.
* Hematological: He has thrombocytopenia and anemia, and is being treated with blood transfusions and platelet infusions.

Potential Complications:

Based on the patient's current status, potential complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemia and respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further respiratory complications such as ARDS.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension may lead to cardiac arrest if not managed properly.
* Renal failure: The patient's oliguric acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further complications such as electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
* Sepsis: The patient's septic shock may worsen, leading to further complications such as multiorgan failure and death.
* Pancreatitis: The patient's gallstone pancreatitis may worsen, leading to further complications such as necrotizing pancreatitis and pancreatic abscess.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to further complications such as bleeding and hemorrhage.

Plan:

Based on the patient's current status and potential complications, the plan is as follows:

* Continue mechanical ventilation and vasopressors to maintain blood pressure and oxygenation.
* Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilator settings as necessary.
* Continue to treat the patient's septic shock with antibiotics and vasopressors.
* Monitor the patient's renal status closely and adjust CVVH settings as necessary.
* Continue to treat the patient's pancreatitis with ERCP and CBD stent placement.
* Monitor the patient's thrombocytopenia and anemia closely and adjust treatment as necessary.
* Continue to trend the patient's laboratory values and adjust treatment as necessary.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and improve his chances of recovery.

   Assessment and Plan
   55 yo male with pmh of htn and asthma trasnferred from an OSH for
   worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock complicated by
   hypoxic respiratory failure and oliguric acute renal failure.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  ARDS likely as p/f ratio consistently
   in 80s. Has had difficulty maintaining oxygenation, despite alveolar
   recruitment maneuvers, positioning of bed, very elevated PEEP,
   esophageal balloon pressures but recently stable in 90s % O2sat w 100%
   FiO2.  Change of bed with 35 degree tilting appeared to help but
   difficult to do accurate CVVH w bed tilted, so he is supine.
   - Keep PEEP at 26 (or higher) but do not want to derecruit alveoli
   - Decrease FiO2 and check ABGs to get paO2 in 60s for ARDS protocol
   - Midazolam and fentanyl prn for sedation
   - Continue bed positioning as tolerated to help improve increased
   perfusion to more ventilated areas
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  Weaned off levophed this AM. Continues on
   Vasopressin.  Continues to be febrile
   - Cont vasopressin to maintain MAPs>65.
   - trend fever curve ; CVVH will bring temperatures down, so he may not
   be spiking fevers though he otherwise may have
   - culture if spikes through CVVH ; attempt PR Tylenol again
   - f/u  blood cultures, Ucx
s and sputum cultures (negative so far)
   - Zosyn, renally dosed due to concern for possible cholangitis +
   Vancomycin renally dosed
   - check again w OSH about cultures to see if still negative; can peel
   off Vancomycin if all still negative because we need to cover mostly Gm
   Negs from biliary system
   .
   # Acute renal failure:
   Cr  increased still very high but cannot monitor anymore because on
   CVVH.  Likely  ATN highest on differential at this point. Started CVVH
   yesterday afternoon
   - Continue CVVH to get fluids off
 increase rate from 50cc/hr to
   100cc/hr to see how he tolerates b/c BPs are better this AM
   - dose medications for CVVH
   - Follow bladder pressures and lactate
 if continuing to increase
   consider calling surgery to assess for possible decompression of
   compartment syndrome
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient on amio gtt in sinus rhythm. Dilt drip
   stopped yesterday
   -  Continue amio gtt for now for entire loading dose
   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   - cannot transition to PO amiodarone but need a way to maintain
   rhythm/rate in long-term once amio load complete
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stent placed by ERCP fellow.  Improving
   lipase and amylase
   - f/u ERCP/GI recs
   - Will f/u surgery recs.
   - NPO with IVF
bolus as needed for pressures or give back fluid w CVVH
   - Trend his LFTs and pancreatic enzymes
   .
   # Hyperglycemia:  The patient does not have known history of diabetes,
   however was found to have sugars in the 500's at the OSH so he likely
   had underlying type II diabetes.  Controlled on an insulin gtt.
   - Continue insulin gtt for now.
   .
   # Anemia: The patient's Hct decreased to 31 (from 52 at OSH when
   hemoconcentrated) but stable currently.  Guaiac + diarrhea + fluids
   - Active type and screen.
   - Transfuse if Hct < 25
   - Continue to trend.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia:  His platelets are trending down slowly.  Low
   suspicion for HIT, but HIT antibody sent, and subq heparin DCed
   yesterday.  [**Month (only) 8**] be secondary to Zosyn. (platelets 202 at outside
   hospital admission)
   - Continue to trend.

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma, who was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. He has been treated with vasopressin for hypotension and septic shock, and has been started on CVVH for acute renal failure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 92 bpm, blood pressure of 106/55 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 95% on 100% FiO2. His respiratory status is stable, with a PEEP of 26 cmH2O and a FiO2 of 100%. His abdominal compartment syndrome is being monitored, with a bladder pressure of 15 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of creatinine, lactate, and lipase, and decreased levels of platelets and albumin. He has been treated with antibiotics, anticoagulation therapy, and insulin therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure is a significant risk factor for respiratory failure, particularly with the use of high PEEP and FiO2.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's oliguric acute renal failure is a risk factor for acute kidney injury, particularly with the use of CVVH.
3. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is a risk factor for sepsis, particularly with the use of vasopressin and antibiotics.
4. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's abdominal compartment syndrome is a risk factor for abdominal compartment syndrome, particularly with the use of CVVH and vasopressin.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is a risk factor for bleeding, particularly with the use of anticoagulation therapy.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia is a risk factor for complications, particularly with the use of insulin therapy.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is a risk factor for complications, particularly with the use of blood transfusions.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust PEEP and FiO2 as necessary.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust CVVH as necessary.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's septic shock and adjust vasopressin and antibiotics as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's abdominal compartment syndrome and adjust CVVH and vasopressin as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's thrombocytopenia and adjust anticoagulation therapy as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's hyperglycemia and adjust insulin therapy as necessary.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and adjust blood transfusions as necessary.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU with gallstone pancreatitis, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute renal failure (ARF), and hypotension requiring pressor support. The patient remains critically ill with a poor prognosis.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.8°F (38.8°C)
* Heart rate: 90 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 114/55 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 29 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* SpO2: 96%

The patient has a history of gallstone pancreatitis, and his laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 7.7 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 10.8 g/dL
* Platelet count: 105 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 8.4 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 19 mg/dL
* Sodium: 135 mmol/L
* Potassium: 4.7 mmol/L
* Chloride: 89 mmol/L
* Bicarbonate: 25 mmol/L
* Glucose: 167 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.8 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.6 g/dL
* LDH: 960 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.4 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 4.0 mg/dL

The patient's respiratory status is:

* Oxygenation is improving slightly with volume removal and increased positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP)
* The patient remains on high PEEP and FIO2 requirements
* The patient has ARDS with bilateral effusion and atelectasis

The patient's cardiac status is:

* The patient has atrial fibrillation (AFIB) and is on amiodarone
* The patient's cardiac rhythm is now in normal sinus rhythm (NSR)

The patient's renal status is:

* The patient has acute renal failure (ARF) and is on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH)
* The patient's creatinine level is 8.4 mg/dL

The patient's nutritional status is:

* The patient is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) without lipids
* The patient's glycemic control is being maintained with insulin infusion

The patient's thrombocytopenia is suspected to be related to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

The patient's septic shock is suspected to be related to pancreatitis and cholangitis/gallbladder source.

The patient's prognosis is poor, and the patient is critically ill.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis and septic shock
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Acute renal failure (ARF)
* Pancreatitis and cholangitis/gallbladder source
* Thrombocytopenia and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT)
* Hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia
* Hypotension and shock
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Neurological complications
* Infection and sepsis
* Multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS)

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) for acute renal failure (ARF)
* Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) without lipids for nutritional support
* Insulin infusion for glycemic control
* Amiodarone for atrial fibrillation (AFIB)
* Vasopressin for septic shock and hypotension
* Empiric vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for sepsis and infection
* Prophylactic antibiotics for stress ulcer and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) prevention
* Monitoring for sepsis, ARDS, and MODS

   Agree with plan to continue aggressive supportive care for GS
   pancreatitis and MODS.  He remains very tenuous from resp standpoint
   with high peep and fio2 requirements in setting of ards and large
   distended abd. Oxygenation has improved slightly with volume removal
   and increased peep.   Will continue ACV w/ ards net TVs, high peep
   guiding with esoph balloon. Will wean O2 as able to maintain paO2 > 60,
   following abgs closely. We continue to follow his bladder pressures to
   monitor for abd compartment syndrome as his very distended abd is
   contributing to his high peep needs..
   The most likely source of his continued temp is severe pancreatitis w/
   inflammation.  He is s/p ercp with CBD stone removal and stent and his
   enzymes and lfts are trending down.  We continue empiric vanco/zosyn
   Day 3 with cx data neg to date.  Will consider d/cing vanco once we
   confirm that osh cxs remain neg.
   He remains on cvvh and we will attempt increased volume removal as BP
   tolerates maintaining MAPS > 60.  Will try to d/c pressor (vasopressin)
   as able. We continue amio gtt  for load, for prior rapid a-fib,  now in
   nsr. We have a low suspicion for HIT but suspect his thrombocytopenia
   is related to failed liver and sepsis.  Counts remain stable.
   Pt is very ill with multi organ failure and very poor prognosis.  We
   continue to update his HCP and family.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 55-year-old male with severe gallstone pancreatitis complicated by multiorgan dysfunction syndrome (MODS), respiratory failure, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute kidney injury (AKI), and hypotension.
* He remains critically ill with a poor prognosis.
* The patient has a distended abdomen, anasarca, and is on mechanical ventilation with high positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) requirements.

**Potential Complications:**

* **Sepsis:** The patient's persistent fever, high white blood cell count, and elevated inflammatory markers suggest a high risk of sepsis, which can worsen his MODS and increase the risk of organ failure.
* **Abdominal Compartment Syndrome:** The patient's distended abdomen and high bladder pressures increase the risk of abdominal compartment syndrome, which can lead to organ failure and death.
* **ARDS Progression:** The patient's ongoing respiratory failure and high PEEP requirements increase the risk of ARDS progression, which can lead to further respiratory distress and failure.
* **Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) Progression:** The patient's ongoing AKI and high creatinine levels increase the risk of AKI progression, which can lead to end-stage renal disease.
* **Thrombocytopenia:** The patient's thrombocytopenia may be related to liver failure and sepsis, and can increase the risk of bleeding and hemorrhage.
* **Hyperglycemia:** The patient's hyperglycemia may increase the risk of diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome, and other complications.
* **Pulmonary Embolism:** The patient's immobility and hypercoagulable state increase the risk of pulmonary embolism, which can worsen his respiratory failure and increase the risk of mortality.

**Plan:**

* Continue aggressive supportive care for the patient's severe pancreatitis and MODS.
* Monitor the patient's oxygenation closely and wean FiO2 as able to maintain a PaO2 > 60.
* Continue to follow the patient's bladder pressures to monitor for abdominal compartment syndrome.
* Consider discontinuing vancomycin once CX data is negative.
* Attempt to increase volume removal as the patient's blood pressure tolerates, maintaining a mean arterial pressure (MAP) > 60.
* Try to discontinue pressors (vasopressin) as able.
* Continue amiodarone infusion for load, for prior rapid atrial fibrillation, now in normal sinus rhythm.
* Monitor the patient's platelet count and consider platelet transfusions if necessary.
* Continue to update the patient's healthcare provider and family regarding his condition.

   55 yo male with pmh of HTN and asthma trasnferred from an OSH for
   worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock complicated by
   hypoxic respiratory failure and oliguric acute renal failure currently
   on CVVH.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  ARDS likely as p/f ratio 120. Has had
   difficulty maintaining oxygenation, despite alveolar recruitment
   maneuvers, positioning of bed, very elevated PEEP, esophageal balloon
   pressures but recently stable in 90s % O2sat w 60% FiO2.  Change of bed
   with 35 degree tilting appeared to help but difficult to do accurate
   CVVH w bed tilted, so he is supine.
   - Concerning as PIP and Plateau pressures are quite high. ( C=P/V)
   Goals to increase compliance: decrease volume with CVVH; Decrease TV to
   400, and if possible decrease peep (unlikely able to decrease this as
   do not want to de-recruit alveoli any further)
   - Decrease FiO2 and check ABGs to get paO2 in 60s for ARDS protocol
   - Midazolam and fentanyl prn for sedation
   - Continue bed positioning as tolerated to help improve increased
   perfusion to more ventilated areas
   - Continue CVVH with as much volume to take off as can be tolerated to
   help improve oxygenation
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  Weaned off levophed [**9-26**]. Vasopressin
   stopped overnight.  Continues to be febrile and now hypertensive off
   pressors.
   - No longer hypotensive; off pressors. Continue CVVH to increase volume
   removal and hopefully reduce bp some.
   - Consider anti-hypertensives if persistent SBP < 160
   - trend fever curve ; CVVH will bring temperatures down, so he may not
   be spiking fevers though he otherwise may have
   - culture if spikes through CVVH ; attempt PR Tylenol again
   - f/u  blood cultures, Ucx
s and sputum cultures (negative so far)
   - CXR today and if continues to spike consider abdominal CT to rule out
   other sources of possible infection
   - Zosyn, renally dosed due to concern for possible cholangitis; D/C
   Vancomycin as unlikely Gram positive source of infection
   .
   # Acute renal failure:  Cr  slowly coming down, but still very high and
   cannot monitor anymore because on CVVH.  Likely ATN highest on
   differential at this point. Started CVVH Monday afternoon [**9-25**];
   patient tolerating well.
   - Continue CVVH to get fluids off
 increase rate from 150cc/hr to
   150-250cc/hr to see how he tolerates b/c BPs are better this AM
   - dose medications for CVVH
   - Follow bladder pressures and lactate
 if continuing to increase
   consider calling surgery to assess for possible decompression of
   compartment syndrome
   - Renal following: will ask if lasix trial is suitable yet.

   - Continue amio gtt for now for entire loading dose as patient cannot

   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   - Keep track of Amio dosage; once 10 grams is achieved, may need to

   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stent placed by ERCP fellow.  Improving

   - Will f/u surgery recs.
   - NPO with IVF
bolus as needed for pressures or give back fluid w CVVH
   - Trend his LFTs and pancreatic enzymes

   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  ARDS likely as p/f ratio 120. Has had
   difficulty maintaining oxygenation, despite alveolar recruitment
   maneuvers, positioning of bed, very elevated PEEP, esophageal balloon
   pressures but recently stable in 90s % O2sat w 60% FiO2.  Change of bed
   with 35 degree tilting appeared to help but difficult to do accurate
   CVVH w bed tilted, so he is supine.
   - Concerning as PIP and Plateau pressures are quite high. ( C=P/V)

   400, and if possible decrease peep (unlikely able to decrease this as
   do not want to de-recruit alveoli any further)

   - Midazolam and fentanyl prn for sedation
   - Continue bed positioning as tolerated to help improve increased
   perfusion to more ventilated areas
   - Continue CVVH with as much volume to take off as can be tolerated to
   help improve oxygenation
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  Weaned off levophed [**9-26**]. Vasopressin
   stopped overnight.  Continues to be febrile and now hypertensive off
   pressors.
   - No longer hypotensive; off pressors. Continue CVVH to increase volume
   removal and hopefully reduce bp some.

   - f/u  blood cultures, Ucx
s and sputum cultures (negative so far)

   - Zosyn, renally dosed due to concern for possible cholangitis; D/C
   Vancomycin as unlikely Gram positive source of infection
   .
   # Acute renal failure:  Cr  slowly coming down, but still very high and
   cannot monitor anymore because on CVVH.  Likely ATN highest on
   differential at this point. Started CVVH Monday afternoon [**9-25**];
   patient tolerating well.
   - Continue CVVH to get fluids off
 increase rate from 150cc/hr to
   150-250cc/hr to see how he tolerates b/c BPs are better this AM
   - dose medications for CVVH
   - Follow bladder pressures and lactate
 if continuing to increase
   consider calling surgery to assess for possible decompression of

   - Renal following: will ask if lasix trial is suitable yet.
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient on amio gtt in sinus rhythm. Dilt drip

   - Continue amio gtt for now for entire loading dose as patient cannot

   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   - Keep track of Amio dosage; once 10 grams is achieved, may need to

bolus as needed for pressures or give back fluid w CVVH

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma who was transferred from an outside hospital for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. He is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).

The patient's condition has been stable overnight, with his blood pressure (BP) remaining in the 150s-160s mmHg range. His peak pressures have decreased to the 40s, and his respiratory rate (RR) has decreased to 32 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation (SpO2) remains at 96%.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count (WBC) of 8.0 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hb) of 10.8 g/dL, platelet count (Plt) of 102 K/uL, and creatinine (Cr) of 6.5 mg/dL. His lactate level is 23 mmol/L.

The patient is at risk for several medical complications, including:

1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient's PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 120, which is consistent with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He is being managed with a high positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) and a high tidal volume (TV).
2. Hypotension/Septic Shock: The patient's BP has been stable overnight, but he is still at risk for hypotension and septic shock due to his ongoing sepsis and oliguric acute renal failure.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's Cr level is still elevated, and he is at risk for further deterioration in his renal function.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is trending down, and he is at risk for bleeding.
5. Anemia: The patient's Hct level is decreased, and he is at risk for further anemia.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continuing CVVH to remove excess fluids and improve oxygenation.
2. Managing his hypotension with vasopressors as needed.
3. Monitoring his lactate level and adjusting his therapy accordingly.
4. Trending his laboratory results, including his WBC count, Hb level, and platelet count.
5. Considering anti-hypertensive therapy if his BP remains elevated.
6. Continuing his insulin drip to control his hyperglycemia.
7. Monitoring his abdominal CT scan and considering further imaging if his abdominal pain persists.
8. Considering decompression of compartment syndrome if his bladder pressures continue to increase.
9. Continuing his amiodarone drip to control his atrial fibrillation.
10. Monitoring his blood cultures and considering further antibiotic therapy if his infection persists.

   Assessment and Plan
   55 yo male with pmh of HTN and asthma trasnferred from an OSH for
   worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock complicated by
   hypoxic respiratory failure and oliguric acute renal failure currently
   on CVVH.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure:  ARDS likely as p/f ratio 120. Has had
   difficulty maintaining oxygenation, despite alveolar recruitment
   maneuvers, positioning of bed, very elevated PEEP, esophageal balloon
   pressures but recently stable in 90s % O2sat w 60% FiO2.  Change of bed
   with 35 degree tilting appeared to help but difficult to do accurate
   CVVH w bed tilted, so he is supine.
   - Keep PEEP at 26 (or higher) but do not want to derecruit alveoli
   - Decrease FiO2 and check ABGs to get paO2 in 60s for ARDS protocol
   - Midazolam and fentanyl prn for sedation
   - Continue bed positioning as tolerated to help improve increased
   perfusion to more ventilated areas
   - Continue CVVH with as much volume to take off as can be tolerated to
   help improve oxygenation
   .
    # Hypotension/Septic Shock:  Weaned off levophed [**9-26**]. Vasopressin
   stopped overnight.  Continues to be febrile
   - Cont vasopressin to maintain MAPs>65.
   - trend fever curve ; CVVH will bring temperatures down, so he may not
   be spiking fevers though he otherwise may have
   - culture if spikes through CVVH ; attempt PR Tylenol again
   - f/u  blood cultures, Ucx
s and sputum cultures (negative so far)
   - Zosyn, renally dosed due to concern for possible cholangitis +
   Vancomycin renally dosed
   - check again w OSH about cultures to see if still negative; can peel
   off Vancomycin if all still negative because we need to cover mostly Gm
   Negs from biliary system
   .
   # Acute renal failure:
   Cr  increased still very high but cannot monitor anymore because on
   CVVH.  Likely  ATN highest on differential at this point. Started CVVH
   Monday afternoon [**9-25**]; patient tolerating well.
   - Continue CVVH to get fluids off
 increase rate from 150cc/hr to
   150-250cc/hr to see how he tolerates b/c BPs are better this AM
   - dose medications for CVVH
   - Follow bladder pressures and lactate
 if continuing to increase
   consider calling surgery to assess for possible decompression of
   compartment syndrome
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Patient on amio gtt in sinus rhythm. Dilt drip
   stopped [**9-25**]
   - Continue amio gtt for now for entire loading dose as patient cannot
   take po
   - Goal to keep patient
s HR < 120 as to improve CO and perfusion
   - Keep track of Amio dosage; once 10 grams is achieved, may need to
   give maintenance dose through IV (200 mg/day)
   # Gallstone pancreatitis:  CBD stent placed by ERCP fellow.  Improving
   lipase and amylase
   - f/u ERCP/GI recs
   - Will f/u surgery recs.
   - NPO with IVF
bolus as needed for pressures or give back fluid w CVVH
   - Trend his LFTs and pancreatic enzymes
   .
   # Hyperglycemia:  The patient does not have known history of diabetes,
   however was found to have sugars in the 500's at the OSH so he likely
   had underlying type II diabetes.  Controlled on an insulin gtt.
   - Continue insulin gtt for now.
   - Consider Insulin in TPN
   .
   # Anemia: The patient's Hct decreased to 31 (from 52 at OSH when
   hemoconcentrated) but stable currently.  Guaiac + diarrhea + fluids
   - Active type and screen.
   - Transfuse if Hct < 25
   - Continue to trend.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia:  His platelets are trending down slowly.  Low
   suspicion for HIT, but HIT antibody sent, and subq heparin DCed
   yesterday.  [**Month (only) 8**] be secondary to Zosyn. (platelets 202 at outside
   hospital admission)
   - Continue to trend.
   - No signs of active bleeding
   ICU Care

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and asthma who was transferred to the ICU for worsening gallstone pancreatitis leading to septic shock, hypoxic respiratory failure, and oliguric acute renal failure. He is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 163/66 mmHg, heart rate of 92 bpm, and oxygen saturation of 96%. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a peak inspiratory pressure of 46 cmH2O and a plateau pressure of 44 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 8.0 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 10.8 g/dL
* Platelet count: 102 K/uL
* Creatinine: 6.5 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 137 mg/dL
* Glucose: 132 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: Na 137 mg/dL, K 5.3 mEq/L, Cl 102 mEq/L, PO4 3.6 mg/dL
* Liver function tests: ALT 142 IU/L, AST 219 IU/L, Alk Phos 48 IU/L, T Bili 8.6 mg/dL
* Amylase: 200 IU/L
* Lipase: 51 IU/L

The patient's medications include:

* Fentanyl: 100 mcg/hour
* Insulin: 9 units/hour
* Amiodarone: 0.5 mg/min
* Midazolam: 7 mg/hour
* Zosyn: renally dosed
* Vancomycin: renally dosed
* Pantoprazole: 40 mg/day
* Aspirin: 81 mg/day

The patient's clinical status is stable, with no signs of active bleeding. However, he is at risk for developing complications such as:

* Hypotension/Septic Shock: The patient's blood pressure is stable, but he is still at risk for developing hypotension and septic shock.
* Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level is still elevated, and he is at risk for developing acute kidney injury.
* Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's heart rate is stable, but he is at risk for developing atrial fibrillation.
* Gallstone Pancreatitis: The patient's lipase and amylase levels are improving, but he is at risk for developing complications such as pancreatic necrosis and abscess formation.
* Hyperglycemia: The patient's glucose level is controlled, but he is at risk for developing hyperglycemia and its complications.
* Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is stable, but he is at risk for developing anemia and its complications.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is trending down, but he is at risk for developing thrombocytopenia and its complications.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue CVVH to manage his acute renal failure and hyperkalemia.
* Monitor his blood pressure and adjust his vasopressor therapy as needed.
* Continue his insulin therapy to control his hyperglycemia.
* Monitor his platelet count and adjust his platelet transfusions as needed.
* Continue his antibiotics to treat his sepsis.
* Monitor his liver function tests and adjust his medications as needed.
* Continue his anticoagulation therapy to prevent deep vein thrombosis.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for developing complications such as hypotension/Septic Shock, Acute Renal Failure, Atrial Fibrillation, Gallstone Pancreatitis, Hyperglycemia, Anemia, and Thrombocytopenia. His plan of care includes managing his acute renal failure and hyperkalemia with CVVH, monitoring his blood pressure and adjusting his vasopressor therapy as needed, controlling his hyperglycemia with insulin therapy, monitoring his platelet count and adjusting his platelet transfusions as needed, continuing his antibiotics to treat his sepsis, monitoring his liver function tests and adjusting his medications as needed, and continuing his anticoagulation therapy to prevent deep vein thrombosis.
